title: In-Depth Meditation Course for Experienced Practitioners: Year 3 Term 2 (February ‚Äì April 2026)
description:
In-Depth Meditation Training

An apportunity to put the teachings into practice and deepen your meditative experience and understanding, through the guidance of experienced meditator and teacher Venerable Losang Gendun.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Saturdays 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • üïï 3:30 ‚Äì 6:00 PM
  • üè† Online

About This Course – Year 3 – The Radiant Ground: Emptiness and Buddha Nature.

This year‚Äôs journey will weave together the profound view of Madhyamaka, as presented by NƒÅgƒÅrjuna and his successors, with the compassionate vision of TathƒÅgatagarbha, the Buddha-nature teachings that reveal our deepest potential for awakening. Far from abstract philosophy, these teachings offer a radical reorientation of how we perceive ourselves and the world ‚Äî pointing us beyond habitual grasping to a space of clarity, openness, and profound compassion.

Having cultivated the foundational practices of shamatha and vipashyana in the first year and explored YogƒÅcƒÅra‚Äôs profound psychology of ignorance and awakening in the second, we now turn to the very heart of Tibetan Buddhism: the nature of emptiness and the luminous potential that resides within every living being. Guiding us in this exploration will be core texts from India and Tibet. NƒÅgƒÅrjuna‚Äôs M≈´lamadhyamakakƒÅrikƒÅ will serve as a central pillar, systematically dismantling the illusions of inherent existence. In dialogue with this, we‚Äôll study Kamalashƒ´la‚Äôs Stages of Meditation, a practical and accessible map for cultivating deep meditative insight grounded in the view of emptiness.

Balancing the radical freedom of Madhyamaka, we will encounter the warmth and encouragement of Maitreya‚Äôs RatnagotravibhƒÅga, a poetic illumination of the Buddha-nature within all beings. These teachings remind us that beyond confusion and conditioning, there is a basic goodness that has never been lost. To ground these profound insights in daily life, we will also study the beloved text of Geshe Chekawa Yeshe Dorje, The Seven Points of Mind Training. With its pithy slogans and deeply practical tone, it offers tools for transforming adversity and cultivating bodhicitta on and off the cushion.

Throughout the year, our study and practice will be enriched by meditative teachings from both the PƒÅli and Sanskrit s≈´tra traditions, inviting a direct and experiential understanding of emptiness ‚Äî not as a concept, but as a liberating shift in perception. This year is an invitation to let the view of emptiness infuse your practice ‚Äî not as abstract philosophy, but as living experience: clear, liberating, and rooted in compassion. Our aim is not to gather concepts, but to transform how we see and relate to the world. Through study, reflection, and meditation, we learn to meet life with less grasping, more openness ‚Äî and a heart that naturally responds with wisdom and care, held by the strength of community.

The Buddha Project

This meditation course is part of The Buddha Project led by Ven. Losang Gendun, a branch of which is the Buddha Research Project, an on-going collaboration between Buddhist contemplatives and scientific researchers from the universities of N√Æmes and Lausanne, and the Mind & Life organization (founded by neuroscientist Francesco Varela in collaboration with H.H. the Dalai Lama). It is aimed at investigating transformative processes in long-term meditators, regarding such topics as mental health, perception, and self-transcendence. For the initial research it has been granted a European Varela Award.

Introduction to the IDMT training

Meditation is essential for personal transformation and a crucial complement to Buddhist studies. This 4-year online course provides students with long term, in-depth support in their meditative development. This weekly course will offer:

  • Authentic traditional instructions, in contemporary language, aimed at providing a comprehensive set of meditation tools for students to transform their knowledge of the Dharma into personal experience.
  • Traditional and modern theories on supplementary topics such as models of healthy psychological and spiritual development, ritual, narrative, ethics, and social engagement.
  • An international community of meditators, online and live.

To complement the IDMT course we will also offer:

  • Meditation Retreats ‚Äì week & weekend retreats on vipassana, compassion, and mahamudra, offered both at the centers and online.
  • Yogi Bootcamp ‚Äì an intensive, guided, 1-year meditation training with weekly personal interviews (call) for a small group of international students.
  • Practice days guided by Ven. Gendun and experienced students of Ven. Gendun
  • Weekly reflection sessions, led by experienced students
  • Weekends with the opportunity to receive¬†Refuge / Lay Vows, Aspiring Bodhisattva Vows and Engaging Bodhisattva Vows

For more information about the content of the course,¬†download the course description (PDF) here.¬†This course is a collaboration between 5 FPMT Buddhist centers: Shantideva Center New York (US), Jamyang Buddhist Centre Leeds (UK), Institut Vajrayogini in Marzens (FR), Yeshin Norbu Stockholm (SW) and Maitreya Instituut (NL) and therefore the course will be attended by an international group of Buddhist practitioners. If you‚Äôre enrolling later on in the course, it is possible to request access to recordings of previous classes.¬†Practical details¬†The In-Depth Meditation Training runs weekly on Saturdays and consists of about 1-hour of guided meditation and 1,5 hours of teachings. The course offers a great opportunity for Buddhist practitioners. In the first year many of the foundational topics will be introduced, however a basic understanding of Mahayana Buddhism is a prerequisite to attend. It will be given in English, with French translation, online via Zoom. The recordings will be made available after the sessions.

Practical information and how to register:

  • Course dates: 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • Weekday:¬†Saturdays
  • Time:¬†15:30-18:00 European Central Timezone
  • Language:¬†English
  • Location:¬†Online (zoom link will be sent after registration)
  • Donation:¬†drop in 250 SEK, term 2500 SEK, 4 times pass 800 SEK
  • Last day of registration: you can join any time

 

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun has dedicated nearly four decades to practicing Buddhism and has served as a Bhikshu (Buddhist monk) in the Tibetan tradition for the past 18 years. Prior to his ordination, he worked in diverse fields such as palliative care, technology, refugee organizations, and commercial management. His extensive training includes ten years of studying Buddhist philosophy and practice in monasteries across France, India, Nepal, and Myanmar. Additionally, he spent over four years in retreat, immersing himself in Tibetan sutra and tantra, as well as the Burmese Theravada Forest Tradition. For the last 15 years, Ven. Gendun has been a dedicated teacher, sharing his knowledge of Buddhist philosophy, psychology, and meditation worldwide. He serves the aspirations of H.H. the Dalai Lama and Lama Zopa Rinpoche as part of the FPMT (Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition). Ven. Gendun is also a member of Mind & Life Europe, a multidisciplinary laboratory that brings together researchers and contemplative practitioners to explore the nature of experience. Beyond his Buddhist affiliations, Ven. Gendun serves as an interreligious canon at the Peace Cathedral in Tbilisi, Georgia, and feels at home at a Mevlavi Sufi dargah in Istanbul. In 2023, he founded The Buddha Project, which engages in long-term guidance for Buddhist meditators, scientific research, art projects, and intercontemplative social engagement.

title: Kum Nye Course Online
description:
Kum Nye Course Online

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our energy. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. By promoting deep relaxation, the conditions are created to naturally deepen meditative concentration and presence. Everyone can participate regardless of age and physical shape, as the exercises can be adapted to suit one’s own ability.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Stig Albansson

  • üìÖ January 18, February 1 and 15, March 1, 15 and 29, April 12 and 19
  • üïï 10:00 – 11:30
  • üè† Online

About the Course

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our inner energies. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. In this course of eight sessions, experienced Kum Nye practitioner and teacher Stig Albansson will guide you through practices from the book Kum Nye Tibetan Yoga by Tartang Tulku, that can then be practiced the weeks between each session.

The book is available for sale from Yeshin Norbu, if you are interested to purchase a copy please reach out to: hello@yeshinnorbu.se.

About the Teacher

Stig Albansson m√∂tte Kum Nye under en 6 m√•naders kurs/retreat p√• Nyingma Institute i Berkeley i Kalifornien, 1996-97. Stig har lett praktikgrupper i Kum Nye p√• F√∂reningen f√∂r tibetansk buddhism i G√∂teborg sedan -98, och fr√•n 2015 g√•tt flera av de l√§rarutbildningar i Kum Nye som organiserats av Dharma Publishing. Efter det har ett flertal kurser och retreater getts, bland annat p√• Yeshin Norbu 2020. Fr√•n 2017 har ocks√• mycket undervisning erbjudits online, och sedan januari i √•r h√•ller Stig i Kum Nye tre morgnar i veckan via Zoom.

title: Free Monday Meditation
description:
Monday Free Drop – in Meditation

Join our drop-in meditations to make meditation part of your daily routine. Even short meditations help you relax and regain focus. This term our resident teacher Venerable Khadro will introduce meditations inspired by the 16 Guidelines.

Event Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Mondays starting from January 12th (except for April 6th)
  • üïï 6.00 – 7.00pm
  • üè† Hybrid

About this Event

Do you sometimes feel stressed, worried or distracted? Brain research has shown that mindfulness and meditation can help us develop more focus, become more relaxed and create greater mental clarity. Join our drop-in meditations to make meditation part of your daily routine. Even short meditations help you relax and regain focus.

This term our resident teacher Venerable Khadro will introduce meditations inspired by the 16 Guidelines. For more information about the 16 Guidelines follow this link:

16 Guidelines for Life

Everyone is welcome, regardless of previous experience of meditation and mindfulness. If there are beginners we adapt to this. For those who are more experienced this is a great opportunity to sustain a regular meditation practice.

Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/85118706540?pwd=g2am9GosamcCybdasIB0YeIiA9KY93.1

Meeting ID: 851 1870 6540
Passcode: meditation

About the Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

title: Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro – For more experienced students – Part 1
description:
Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro – For more experienced students

This spring, Venerable Khadro will for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Tuesdays 27 January, 3, 10, 17, 24 February, 3, 10 March
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM including Fika
  • üè† Hybrid

About This Course

This spring, Venerable Khadro will¬† for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices, particularly one sadana adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche did on many occasions adviced his students to perform what he called “The Method to Transform a Suffering Life into Happiness” – a compilation of daily practices, including prayers, sadanas and meditations for both the beginning, middle and the end of the day.

Following Rinpoche’s advice Venerable Khadro will begin the year by introducing this essential daily practice. For more information about the practice, please read this short article, including a video about it.

The term is divided into three parts, each part run for about 7 weeks each, it is possible to register for the whole term or the various parts individually. Combined with these classes there will also be offered a number of related practice days and weekend retreats.

A prerequisite to participate in this course is that the student have undertaken the two year Discovering Buddhism course or equivalent.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. Rooted in the VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs rich lineage, this course explores the foundations of deity yoga, the stages of generation and completion, and the role of guru devotion, mantra, and visualization. We practice tantra not to escape the world, but to transmute it ‚Äî recognizing all appearances as expressions of enlightened mind. It is a path of fearless compassion, unshakable clarity, and skillful means. This course is intended for those who have studied the Lam Rim, are already grounded in the sutra path and ready to deepen their understanding of VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs profound methods.

In the event of any enquiries please reach out to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

title: Discovering Buddhism: How to Meditate
description:
Discovering Buddhism: How to Meditate

Begin your journey into Buddhist philosophy and meditation with the second module of Discovering Buddhism.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Thursdays 5, 12, 19, 26 March & 2 April
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM
  • üè† Hybrid (March 5 class will be offered online only)

About This Course

In this module of Discovering Buddhism you will learn about the definition and purpose of meditation, how to sit properly, how to set up a meditation session, how to recognize and deal with obstacles to meditation, and will get to experiment with different types of meditation techniques.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

 

Course Preview

For more information about this module, watch this 26-minute video on Youtube:

Part of the internationally renowned Discovering Buddhism program, developed by the Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition (FPMT).
Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

title: Heart Medicine: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Wellbeing – Public Talk with Venerable Losang Gendun
description:
Heart Medicine: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Wellbeing

Our much-appreciated teacher Venerable Losang Gendun will explore the transformative power of warm-heartedness as a foundation for genuine wellbeing during this public talk.

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Friday 6 March
  • üïï 6:00 – 7:30 PM
  • üè† Hybrid: Join in-person or online

About this Event

Our much-appreciated teacher Venerable Losang Gendun will explore the transformative power of warm-heartedness as a foundation for genuine wellbeing during this public talk. Venerable Gendun will illuminate how kindness and compassion can be clear-eyed, grounded tools‚Äîboth for spiritual development and robust engagement with a complex
world. Drawing on the Mahayana Buddhist tradition, which reveals how our minds contain extraordinary qualities that guide us toward inner and social freedom, Venerable Gendun

will share practical methods for nurturing these essential qualities. These accessible techniques can be integrated into daily life, whether navigating workplace stress, family
relationships, or inner struggles. Everyone is welcome, regardless of background or familiarity with Buddhism. Whether you are curious about meditation, seeking greater peace of mind, or looking to deepen existing practice, this talk offers valuable guidance. No prior knowledge required.

About the Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun is a Dutch Buddhist teacher and monk. After practicing mainly Theravada Buddhism for twenty years, he became a monk in the Tibetan tradition in 2006. At the Nalanda monastery in France, he studied Buddhist philosophy for nine years. In all,¬† Venerable Gendun spent more than four years in retreat. Venerable Gendun specializes in the Tibetan Lojong and Mahamudra methods, as well as Vipassana-shamatha meditation as taught in the Theravada forest tradition. At Yeshin Norbu he also leads the In-Depth Meditation Training program online.

title: Beyond the Illusion: A Weekend Journey Through Emptiness – Teaching Weekend with Venerable Losang Gendun
description:
Beyond the Illusion: A Weekend Journey Through Emptiness – Teaching Weekend with Venerable Losang Gendun

Join us for a transformative weekend with Venerable Losang Gendun as we explore one of Buddhism’s most profound insights: emptiness (≈õ≈´nyatƒÅ). Whether you are new to Buddhism or deepening existing practice, you will this weekend gain practical tools for understanding how things exist, – transforming your relationship with anxiety, attachment and distress, through increased awareness of your innate wisdom of heart and mind.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Saturday March 7
  • 10 am – 15:00 (teaching) pm and 15:30 – 18:00 (IDMT course; strongly suggested to attend for all; link: https://us02web.zoom.us/j/83137969630?pwd=maQlGt7Lbub6YeUrwvltokfFuLbsG2.1 (Passcode: 493210))
  • Sunday March 8
  • 10 – 16.00 pm
  • üè† Hybrid

About this Teaching Weekend

Join us for a transformative weekend with Venerable Losang Gendun as we explore one of Buddhism’s most profound insights: emptiness (≈õ≈´nyatƒÅ). We will journey through the four major Buddhist philosophical schools recognized in Tibetan tradition‚ÄîVaibhƒÅ·π£ika, SautrƒÅntika, YogƒÅcƒÅra, and Madhyamaka‚Äîdiscovering how each system progressively
deepens our understanding of reality’s ultimate nature. Through guided meditation, contemplation, and accessible discussion, Venerable Gendun will trace the evolution from foundational views on non-self to explorations of subject- object duality and the fundamental interdependence of all phenomena, examining their psychological, social, environmental, and political consequences. The weekend culminates in Je Tsongkhapa’s distinctive PrƒÅsa·πÖgika interpretation‚Äîrenowned for its radical deconstruction of inherent existence while maintaining the validity of conventional reality

No philosophy degree required! We’ll translate ancient wisdom into contemporary language, using everyday examples and experiential exercises. Whether you are new to Buddhism or deepening existing practice, you will gain practical tools for understanding how things exist, transforming your relationship with anxiety, attachment, and the solidity we project onto experience. Discover how emptiness isn’t merely negation but the key to compassion, wisdom, and genuine presence in our complex modern world.

About the Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun is a Dutch Buddhist teacher and monk. After practicing mainly Theravada Buddhism for twenty years, he became a monk in the Tibetan tradition in 2006. At the Nalanda monastery in France, he studied Buddhist philosophy for nine years. In all,¬† Venerable Gendun spent more than four years in retreat. Venerable Gendun specializes in the Tibetan Lojong and Mahamudra methods, as well as Vipassana-shamatha meditation as taught in the Theravada forest tradition. At Yeshin Norbu he also leads the In-Depth Meditation Training program online.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. title: In-Depth Meditation Course for Experienced Practitioners: Year 3 Term 2 (February ‚Äì April 2026)
description:
In-Depth Meditation Training

An apportunity to put the teachings into practice and deepen your meditative experience and understanding, through the guidance of experienced meditator and teacher Venerable Losang Gendun.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Saturdays 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • üïï 3:30 ‚Äì 6:00 PM
  • üè† Online

About This Course – Year 3 – The Radiant Ground: Emptiness and Buddha Nature.

This year‚Äôs journey will weave together the profound view of Madhyamaka, as presented by NƒÅgƒÅrjuna and his successors, with the compassionate vision of TathƒÅgatagarbha, the Buddha-nature teachings that reveal our deepest potential for awakening. Far from abstract philosophy, these teachings offer a radical reorientation of how we perceive ourselves and the world ‚Äî pointing us beyond habitual grasping to a space of clarity, openness, and profound compassion.

Having cultivated the foundational practices of shamatha and vipashyana in the first year and explored YogƒÅcƒÅra‚Äôs profound psychology of ignorance and awakening in the second, we now turn to the very heart of Tibetan Buddhism: the nature of emptiness and the luminous potential that resides within every living being. Guiding us in this exploration will be core texts from India and Tibet. NƒÅgƒÅrjuna‚Äôs M≈´lamadhyamakakƒÅrikƒÅ will serve as a central pillar, systematically dismantling the illusions of inherent existence. In dialogue with this, we‚Äôll study Kamalashƒ´la‚Äôs Stages of Meditation, a practical and accessible map for cultivating deep meditative insight grounded in the view of emptiness.

Balancing the radical freedom of Madhyamaka, we will encounter the warmth and encouragement of Maitreya‚Äôs RatnagotravibhƒÅga, a poetic illumination of the Buddha-nature within all beings. These teachings remind us that beyond confusion and conditioning, there is a basic goodness that has never been lost. To ground these profound insights in daily life, we will also study the beloved text of Geshe Chekawa Yeshe Dorje, The Seven Points of Mind Training. With its pithy slogans and deeply practical tone, it offers tools for transforming adversity and cultivating bodhicitta on and off the cushion.

Throughout the year, our study and practice will be enriched by meditative teachings from both the PƒÅli and Sanskrit s≈´tra traditions, inviting a direct and experiential understanding of emptiness ‚Äî not as a concept, but as a liberating shift in perception. This year is an invitation to let the view of emptiness infuse your practice ‚Äî not as abstract philosophy, but as living experience: clear, liberating, and rooted in compassion. Our aim is not to gather concepts, but to transform how we see and relate to the world. Through study, reflection, and meditation, we learn to meet life with less grasping, more openness ‚Äî and a heart that naturally responds with wisdom and care, held by the strength of community.

The Buddha Project

This meditation course is part of The Buddha Project led by Ven. Losang Gendun, a branch of which is the Buddha Research Project, an on-going collaboration between Buddhist contemplatives and scientific researchers from the universities of N√Æmes and Lausanne, and the Mind & Life organization (founded by neuroscientist Francesco Varela in collaboration with H.H. the Dalai Lama). It is aimed at investigating transformative processes in long-term meditators, regarding such topics as mental health, perception, and self-transcendence. For the initial research it has been granted a European Varela Award.

Introduction to the IDMT training

Meditation is essential for personal transformation and a crucial complement to Buddhist studies. This 4-year online course provides students with long term, in-depth support in their meditative development. This weekly course will offer:

  • Authentic traditional instructions, in contemporary language, aimed at providing a comprehensive set of meditation tools for students to transform their knowledge of the Dharma into personal experience.
  • Traditional and modern theories on supplementary topics such as models of healthy psychological and spiritual development, ritual, narrative, ethics, and social engagement.
  • An international community of meditators, online and live.

To complement the IDMT course we will also offer:

  • Meditation Retreats ‚Äì week & weekend retreats on vipassana, compassion, and mahamudra, offered both at the centers and online.
  • Yogi Bootcamp ‚Äì an intensive, guided, 1-year meditation training with weekly personal interviews (call) for a small group of international students.
  • Practice days guided by Ven. Gendun and experienced students of Ven. Gendun
  • Weekly reflection sessions, led by experienced students
  • Weekends with the opportunity to receive¬†Refuge / Lay Vows, Aspiring Bodhisattva Vows and Engaging Bodhisattva Vows

For more information about the content of the course,¬†download the course description (PDF) here.¬†This course is a collaboration between 5 FPMT Buddhist centers: Shantideva Center New York (US), Jamyang Buddhist Centre Leeds (UK), Institut Vajrayogini in Marzens (FR), Yeshin Norbu Stockholm (SW) and Maitreya Instituut (NL) and therefore the course will be attended by an international group of Buddhist practitioners. If you‚Äôre enrolling later on in the course, it is possible to request access to recordings of previous classes.¬†Practical details¬†The In-Depth Meditation Training runs weekly on Saturdays and consists of about 1-hour of guided meditation and 1,5 hours of teachings. The course offers a great opportunity for Buddhist practitioners. In the first year many of the foundational topics will be introduced, however a basic understanding of Mahayana Buddhism is a prerequisite to attend. It will be given in English, with French translation, online via Zoom. The recordings will be made available after the sessions.

Practical information and how to register:

  • Course dates: 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • Weekday:¬†Saturdays
  • Time:¬†15:30-18:00 European Central Timezone
  • Language:¬†English
  • Location:¬†Online (zoom link will be sent after registration)
  • Donation:¬†drop in 250 SEK, term 2500 SEK, 4 times pass 800 SEK
  • Last day of registration: you can join any time

 

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun has dedicated nearly four decades to practicing Buddhism and has served as a Bhikshu (Buddhist monk) in the Tibetan tradition for the past 18 years. Prior to his ordination, he worked in diverse fields such as palliative care, technology, refugee organizations, and commercial management. His extensive training includes ten years of studying Buddhist philosophy and practice in monasteries across France, India, Nepal, and Myanmar. Additionally, he spent over four years in retreat, immersing himself in Tibetan sutra and tantra, as well as the Burmese Theravada Forest Tradition. For the last 15 years, Ven. Gendun has been a dedicated teacher, sharing his knowledge of Buddhist philosophy, psychology, and meditation worldwide. He serves the aspirations of H.H. the Dalai Lama and Lama Zopa Rinpoche as part of the FPMT (Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition). Ven. Gendun is also a member of Mind & Life Europe, a multidisciplinary laboratory that brings together researchers and contemplative practitioners to explore the nature of experience. Beyond his Buddhist affiliations, Ven. Gendun serves as an interreligious canon at the Peace Cathedral in Tbilisi, Georgia, and feels at home at a Mevlavi Sufi dargah in Istanbul. In 2023, he founded The Buddha Project, which engages in long-term guidance for Buddhist meditators, scientific research, art projects, and intercontemplative social engagement.

title: Kum Nye Course Online
description:
Kum Nye Course Online

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our energy. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. By promoting deep relaxation, the conditions are created to naturally deepen meditative concentration and presence. Everyone can participate regardless of age and physical shape, as the exercises can be adapted to suit one’s own ability.

About the Course

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our inner energies. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. In this course of eight sessions, experienced Kum Nye practitioner and teacher Stig Albansson will guide you through practices from the book Kum Nye Tibetan Yoga by Tartang Tulku, that can then be practiced the weeks between each session.

The book is available for sale from Yeshin Norbu, if you are interested to purchase a copy please reach out to: hello@yeshinnorbu.se.

title: Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro¬†– For more experienced students – Part 2
description:
Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro – For more experienced students

This spring, Venerable Khadro will for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Tuesdays 17, 24, 31 March, 14, 21, 28 April
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM including Fika
  • üè† Hybrid

About This Course

This spring, Venerable Khadro will¬† for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices, particularly one sadana adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche did on many occasions adviced his students to perform what he called “The Method to Transform a Suffering Life into Happiness” – a compilation of daily practices, including prayers, sadanas and meditations for both the beginning, middle and the end of the day.

Following Rinpoche’s advice Venerable Khadro will begin the year by introducing this essential daily practice. For more information about the practice, please read this short article, including a video about it.

The term is divided into three parts, each part run for about 7 weeks each, it is possible to register for the whole term or the various parts individually. Combined with these classes there will also be offered a number of related practice days and weekend retreats.

A prerequisite to participate in this course is that the student have undertaken the two year Discovering Buddhism course or equivalent.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. Rooted in the VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs rich lineage, this course explores the foundations of deity yoga, the stages of generation and completion, and the role of guru devotion, mantra, and visualization. We practice tantra not to escape the world, but to transmute it ‚Äî recognizing all appearances as expressions of enlightened mind. It is a path of fearless compassion, unshakable clarity, and skillful means. This course is intended for those who have studied the Lam Rim, are already grounded in the sutra path and ready to deepen their understanding of VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs profound methods.

In the event of any enquiries please reach out to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

About This Course

In this module of Discovering Buddhism you will learn about the definition and purpose of meditation, how to sit properly, how to set up a meditation session, how to recognize and deal with obstacles to meditation, and will get to experiment with different types of meditation techniques.

 

Your Teacher

title: In-Depth Meditation Course for Experienced Practitioners: Year 3 Term 2 (February ‚Äì April 2026)
description:
In-Depth Meditation Training

An apportunity to put the teachings into practice and deepen your meditative experience and understanding, through the guidance of experienced meditator and teacher Venerable Losang Gendun.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Saturdays 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • üïï 3:30 ‚Äì 6:00 PM
  • üè† Online

About This Course – Year 3 – The Radiant Ground: Emptiness and Buddha Nature.

This year‚Äôs journey will weave together the profound view of Madhyamaka, as presented by NƒÅgƒÅrjuna and his successors, with the compassionate vision of TathƒÅgatagarbha, the Buddha-nature teachings that reveal our deepest potential for awakening. Far from abstract philosophy, these teachings offer a radical reorientation of how we perceive ourselves and the world ‚Äî pointing us beyond habitual grasping to a space of clarity, openness, and profound compassion.

Having cultivated the foundational practices of shamatha and vipashyana in the first year and explored YogƒÅcƒÅra‚Äôs profound psychology of ignorance and awakening in the second, we now turn to the very heart of Tibetan Buddhism: the nature of emptiness and the luminous potential that resides within every living being. Guiding us in this exploration will be core texts from India and Tibet. NƒÅgƒÅrjuna‚Äôs M≈´lamadhyamakakƒÅrikƒÅ will serve as a central pillar, systematically dismantling the illusions of inherent existence. In dialogue with this, we‚Äôll study Kamalashƒ´la‚Äôs Stages of Meditation, a practical and accessible map for cultivating deep meditative insight grounded in the view of emptiness.

Balancing the radical freedom of Madhyamaka, we will encounter the warmth and encouragement of Maitreya‚Äôs RatnagotravibhƒÅga, a poetic illumination of the Buddha-nature within all beings. These teachings remind us that beyond confusion and conditioning, there is a basic goodness that has never been lost. To ground these profound insights in daily life, we will also study the beloved text of Geshe Chekawa Yeshe Dorje, The Seven Points of Mind Training. With its pithy slogans and deeply practical tone, it offers tools for transforming adversity and cultivating bodhicitta on and off the cushion.

Throughout the year, our study and practice will be enriched by meditative teachings from both the PƒÅli and Sanskrit s≈´tra traditions, inviting a direct and experiential understanding of emptiness ‚Äî not as a concept, but as a liberating shift in perception. This year is an invitation to let the view of emptiness infuse your practice ‚Äî not as abstract philosophy, but as living experience: clear, liberating, and rooted in compassion. Our aim is not to gather concepts, but to transform how we see and relate to the world. Through study, reflection, and meditation, we learn to meet life with less grasping, more openness ‚Äî and a heart that naturally responds with wisdom and care, held by the strength of community.

The Buddha Project

This meditation course is part of The Buddha Project led by Ven. Losang Gendun, a branch of which is the Buddha Research Project, an on-going collaboration between Buddhist contemplatives and scientific researchers from the universities of N√Æmes and Lausanne, and the Mind & Life organization (founded by neuroscientist Francesco Varela in collaboration with H.H. the Dalai Lama). It is aimed at investigating transformative processes in long-term meditators, regarding such topics as mental health, perception, and self-transcendence. For the initial research it has been granted a European Varela Award.

Introduction to the IDMT training

Meditation is essential for personal transformation and a crucial complement to Buddhist studies. This 4-year online course provides students with long term, in-depth support in their meditative development. This weekly course will offer:

  • Authentic traditional instructions, in contemporary language, aimed at providing a comprehensive set of meditation tools for students to transform their knowledge of the Dharma into personal experience.
  • Traditional and modern theories on supplementary topics such as models of healthy psychological and spiritual development, ritual, narrative, ethics, and social engagement.
  • An international community of meditators, online and live.

To complement the IDMT course we will also offer:

  • Meditation Retreats ‚Äì week & weekend retreats on vipassana, compassion, and mahamudra, offered both at the centers and online.
  • Yogi Bootcamp ‚Äì an intensive, guided, 1-year meditation training with weekly personal interviews (call) for a small group of international students.
  • Practice days guided by Ven. Gendun and experienced students of Ven. Gendun
  • Weekly reflection sessions, led by experienced students
  • Weekends with the opportunity to receive¬†Refuge / Lay Vows, Aspiring Bodhisattva Vows and Engaging Bodhisattva Vows

For more information about the content of the course,¬†download the course description (PDF) here.¬†This course is a collaboration between 5 FPMT Buddhist centers: Shantideva Center New York (US), Jamyang Buddhist Centre Leeds (UK), Institut Vajrayogini in Marzens (FR), Yeshin Norbu Stockholm (SW) and Maitreya Instituut (NL) and therefore the course will be attended by an international group of Buddhist practitioners. If you‚Äôre enrolling later on in the course, it is possible to request access to recordings of previous classes.¬†Practical details¬†The In-Depth Meditation Training runs weekly on Saturdays and consists of about 1-hour of guided meditation and 1,5 hours of teachings. The course offers a great opportunity for Buddhist practitioners. In the first year many of the foundational topics will be introduced, however a basic understanding of Mahayana Buddhism is a prerequisite to attend. It will be given in English, with French translation, online via Zoom. The recordings will be made available after the sessions.

Practical information and how to register:

  • Course dates: 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • Weekday:¬†Saturdays
  • Time:¬†15:30-18:00 European Central Timezone
  • Language:¬†English
  • Location:¬†Online (zoom link will be sent after registration)
  • Donation:¬†drop in 250 SEK, term 2500 SEK, 4 times pass 800 SEK
  • Last day of registration: you can join any time

 

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun has dedicated nearly four decades to practicing Buddhism and has served as a Bhikshu (Buddhist monk) in the Tibetan tradition for the past 18 years. Prior to his ordination, he worked in diverse fields such as palliative care, technology, refugee organizations, and commercial management. His extensive training includes ten years of studying Buddhist philosophy and practice in monasteries across France, India, Nepal, and Myanmar. Additionally, he spent over four years in retreat, immersing himself in Tibetan sutra and tantra, as well as the Burmese Theravada Forest Tradition. For the last 15 years, Ven. Gendun has been a dedicated teacher, sharing his knowledge of Buddhist philosophy, psychology, and meditation worldwide. He serves the aspirations of H.H. the Dalai Lama and Lama Zopa Rinpoche as part of the FPMT (Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition). Ven. Gendun is also a member of Mind & Life Europe, a multidisciplinary laboratory that brings together researchers and contemplative practitioners to explore the nature of experience. Beyond his Buddhist affiliations, Ven. Gendun serves as an interreligious canon at the Peace Cathedral in Tbilisi, Georgia, and feels at home at a Mevlavi Sufi dargah in Istanbul. In 2023, he founded The Buddha Project, which engages in long-term guidance for Buddhist meditators, scientific research, art projects, and intercontemplative social engagement.

title: Kum Nye Course Online
description:
Kum Nye Course Online

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our energy. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. By promoting deep relaxation, the conditions are created to naturally deepen meditative concentration and presence. Everyone can participate regardless of age and physical shape, as the exercises can be adapted to suit one’s own ability.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Stig Albansson

  • üìÖ January 18, February 1 and 15, March 1, 15 and 29, April 12 and 19
  • üïï 10:00 – 11:30
  • üè† Online

About the Course

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our inner energies. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. In this course of eight sessions, experienced Kum Nye practitioner and teacher Stig Albansson will guide you through practices from the book Kum Nye Tibetan Yoga by Tartang Tulku, that can then be practiced the weeks between each session.

The book is available for sale from Yeshin Norbu, if you are interested to purchase a copy please reach out to: hello@yeshinnorbu.se.

About the Teacher

Stig Albansson m√∂tte Kum Nye under en 6 m√•naders kurs/retreat p√• Nyingma Institute i Berkeley i Kalifornien, 1996-97. Stig har lett praktikgrupper i Kum Nye p√• F√∂reningen f√∂r tibetansk buddhism i G√∂teborg sedan -98, och fr√•n 2015 g√•tt flera av de l√§rarutbildningar i Kum Nye som organiserats av Dharma Publishing. Efter det har ett flertal kurser och retreater getts, bland annat p√• Yeshin Norbu 2020. Fr√•n 2017 har ocks√• mycket undervisning erbjudits online, och sedan januari i √•r h√•ller Stig i Kum Nye tre morgnar i veckan via Zoom.

title: Medicine Buddha Puja
description:
Medicine Buddha Puja

Join us for Medicine Buddha Puja together, a great way to promote healing for ourselves and others.

Event Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Wednesday April 1
  • üïï 6:00 – :8 PM including fika
  • üè† In Person

About This Event

We do Medicine Buddha practice together, led by Venerable Khadro. Group practices create a sense of belonging and add strength to our intentions. It is said that a solitary practice is like a spark, while a group practice is like a raging fire. When we practice together we get support from the group to make our practice more focused, intensive, and deep. The positive effects of our practice spread like ripples on water, so let‚Äôs contribute to peace in the world by practicing together!
In the end of the Medicine Buddha Practice we dedicate the positive energy we have created by doing the practice to the well-being of all sentient beings. We pray and dedicate for individuals as well – for sick, dying, dead, and for success in activities.
Feel free to send your dedications to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.
Most Welcome!

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

Gendun has been a dedicated teacher, sharing his knowledge of Buddhist philosophy, psychology, and meditation worldwide. He serves the aspirations of H.H. the Dalai Lama and Lama Zopa Rinpoche as part of the FPMT (Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition). Ven. Gendun is also a member of Mind & Life Europe, a multidisciplinary laboratory that brings together researchers and contemplative practitioners to explore the nature of experience. Beyond his Buddhist affiliations, Ven. Gendun serves as an interreligious canon at the Peace Cathedral in Tbilisi, Georgia, and feels at home at a Mevlavi Sufi dargah in Istanbul. In 2023, he founded The Buddha Project, which engages in long-term guidance for Buddhist meditators, scientific research, art projects, and intercontemplative social engagement.

title: In-Depth Meditation Course for Experienced Practitioners: Year 3 Term 2 (February ‚Äì April 2026)
description:
In-Depth Meditation Training

An apportunity to put the teachings into practice and deepen your meditative experience and understanding, through the guidance of experienced meditator and teacher Venerable Losang Gendun.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Losang Gendun

  • üìÖ Saturdays 7 Feb ‚Äì 18 April
  • üïï 3:30 ‚Äì 6:00 PM
  • üè† Online

About This Course – Year 3 – The Radiant Ground: Emptiness and Buddha Nature.

This year‚Äôs journey will weave together the profound view of Madhyamaka, as presented by NƒÅgƒÅrjuna and his successors, with the compassionate vision of TathƒÅgatagarbha, the Buddha-nature teachings that reveal our deepest potential for awakening. Far from abstract philosophy, these teachings offer a radical reorientation of how we perceive ourselves and the world ‚Äî pointing us beyond habitual grasping to a space of clarity, openness, and profound compassion.

Having cultivated the foundational practices of shamatha and vipashyana in the first year and explored YogƒÅcƒÅra‚Äôs profound psychology of ignorance and awakening in the second, we now turn to the very heart of Tibetan Buddhism: the nature of emptiness and the luminous potential that resides within every living being. Guiding us in this exploration will be core texts from India and Tibet. NƒÅgƒÅrjuna‚Äôs M≈´lamadhyamakakƒÅrikƒÅ will serve as a central pillar, systematically dismantling the illusions of inherent existence. In dialogue with this, we‚Äôll study Kamalashƒ´la‚Äôs Stages of Meditation, a practical and accessible map for cultivating deep meditative insight grounded in the view of emptiness.

Balancing the radical freedom of Madhyamaka, we will encounter the warmth and encouragement of Maitreya‚Äôs RatnagotravibhƒÅga, a poetic illumination of the Buddha-nature within all beings. These teachings remind us that beyond confusion and conditioning, there is a basic goodness that has never been lost. To ground these profound insights in daily life, we will also study the beloved text of Geshe Chekawa Yeshe Dorje, The Seven Points of Mind Training. With its pithy slogans and deeply practical tone, it offers tools for transforming adversity and cultivating bodhicitta on and off the cushion.

Throughout the year, our study and practice will be enriched by meditative teachings from both the PƒÅli and Sanskrit s≈´tra traditions, inviting a direct and experiential understanding of emptiness ‚Äî not as a concept, but as a liberating shift in perception. This year is an invitation to let the view of emptiness infuse your practice ‚Äî not as abstract philosophy, but as living experience: clear, liberating, and rooted in compassion. Our aim is not to gather concepts, but to transform how we see and relate to the world. Through study, reflection, and meditation, we learn to meet life with less grasping, more openness ‚Äî and a heart that naturally responds with wisdom and care, held by the strength of community.

The Buddha Project

This meditation course is part of The Buddha Project led by Ven. Losang Gendun, a branch of which is the Buddha Research Project, an on-going collaboration between Buddhist contemplatives and scientific researchers from the universities of N√Æmes and Lausanne, and the Mind & Life organization (founded by neuroscientist Francesco Varela in collaboration with H.H. the Dalai Lama). It is aimed at investigating transformative processes in long-term meditators, regarding such topics as mental health, perception, and self-transcendence. For the initial research it has been granted a European Varela Award.

Introduction to the IDMT training

Meditation is essential for personal transformation and a crucial complement to Buddhist studies. This 4-year online course provides students with long term, in-depth support in their meditative development. This weekly course will offer:

  • Authentic traditional instructions, in contemporary language, aimed at providing a comprehensive set of meditation tools for students to transform their knowledge of the Dharma into personal experience.
  • Traditional and modern theories on supplementary topics such as models of healthy psychological and spiritual development, ritual, narrative, ethics, and social engagement.
  • An international community of meditators, online and live.

To complement the IDMT course we will also offer:

  • Meditation Retreats ‚Äì week & weekend retreats on vipassana, compassion, and mahamudra, offered both at the centers and online.
  • Yogi Bootcamp ‚Äì an intensive, guided, 1-year meditation training with weekly personal interviews (call) for a small group of international students.
  • Practice days guided by Ven. Gendun and experienced students of Ven. Gendun
  • Weekly reflection sessions, led by experienced students
  • Weekends with the opportunity to receive¬†Refuge / Lay Vows, Aspiring Bodhisattva Vows and Engaging Bodhisattva Vows

The course offers a great opportunity for Buddhist practitioners. In the first year many of the foundational topics will be introduced, however a basic understanding of Mahayana Buddhism is a prerequisite to attend. Your Teacher

Venerable Losang Gendun has dedicated nearly four decades to practicing Buddhism and has served as a Bhikshu (Buddhist monk) in the Tibetan tradition for the past 18 years. Prior to his ordination, he worked in diverse fields such as palliative care, technology, refugee organizations, and commercial management. His extensive training includes ten years of studying Buddhist philosophy and practice in monasteries across France, India, Nepal, and Myanmar. Additionally, he spent over four years in retreat, immersing himself in Tibetan sutra and tantra, as well as the Burmese Theravada Forest Tradition. For the last 15 years, Ven. Gendun has been a dedicated teacher, sharing his knowledge of Buddhist philosophy, psychology, and meditation worldwide. He serves the aspirations of H.H. the Dalai Lama and Lama Zopa Rinpoche as part of the FPMT (Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition). Ven. Gendun is also a member of Mind & Life Europe, a multidisciplinary laboratory that brings together researchers and contemplative practitioners to explore the nature of experience. Beyond his Buddhist affiliations, Ven. Gendun serves as an interreligious canon at the Peace Cathedral in Tbilisi, Georgia, and feels at home at a Mevlavi Sufi dargah in Istanbul. title: Kum Nye Course Online
description:
Kum Nye Course Online

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our energy. The method was created by the Tibetan lama Tarthang Tulku, primarily to help us who live a hectic life to release stress. By promoting deep relaxation, the conditions are created to naturally deepen meditative concentration and presence. Everyone can participate regardless of age and physical shape, as the exercises can be adapted to suit one’s own ability.

About the Course

Kum Nye is a gentle method that consists of movement and breathing exercises, self-massage and quiet sitting. Healing of the body and mind is supported by reawakening and balancing our inner energies. title: Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro¬†– For more experienced students – Part 2
description:
Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro – For more experienced students

This spring, Venerable Khadro will for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Tuesdays 17, 24, 31 March, 14, 21, 28 April
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM including Fika
  • üè† Hybrid

About This Course

This spring, Venerable Khadro will¬† for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices, particularly one sadana adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche did on many occasions adviced his students to perform what he called “The Method to Transform a Suffering Life into Happiness” – a compilation of daily practices, including prayers, sadanas and meditations for both the beginning, middle and the end of the day.

Following Rinpoche’s advice Venerable Khadro will begin the year by introducing this essential daily practice. For more information about the practice, please read this short article, including a video about it.

The term is divided into three parts, each part run for about 7 weeks each, it is possible to register for the whole term or the various parts individually. Combined with these classes there will also be offered a number of related practice days and weekend retreats.

A prerequisite to participate in this course is that the student have undertaken the two year Discovering Buddhism course or equivalent.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. Rooted in the VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs rich lineage, this course explores the foundations of deity yoga, the stages of generation and completion, and the role of guru devotion, mantra, and visualization. We practice tantra not to escape the world, but to transmute it ‚Äî recognizing all appearances as expressions of enlightened mind. It is a path of fearless compassion, unshakable clarity, and skillful means. This course is intended for those who have studied the Lam Rim, are already grounded in the sutra path and ready to deepen their understanding of VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs profound methods.

In the event of any enquiries please reach out to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

title: Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path
description:
Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path

Begin your journey into Buddhist philosophy and meditation with the third module of Discovering Buddhism. One does not need to be a Buddhist to join this course; it’s suitable for those students who are relatively new to buddhism and would like to gain a better understanding of the entire Buddhist path and also for more experienced students who wish to refresh their understanding of the stages of the path to enlightenment.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Thursdays 16, 23 April & Thursdays 7, 14, 21 May
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM CET
  • üè† Hybrid (in person at Yeshin Norbu/Stockholm and on zoom; recordings will be rent to participants)

About This Course

In this course you will gain a clear idea of the path to enlightenment, especially its three main components: renunciation, Bodhichitta, and the right view of emptiness. You will understand the progressive, step-like structure of the Buddhist path (Lam Rim), its origin in the teachings of Guru Shakyamuni Buddha, the three scopes, where you fit at your present stage of spiritual development, what you need to do next, and how you get from there to enlightenment.

The stages of the path to enlightenment (lamrim in Tibetan) are Shakyamuni Buddha‚Äôs original teachings presented as a logical and gradual system for learning to develop the mind. Arranged in Tibet by Lama Atisha in the eleventh century, the lamrim was subsequently elaborated by other great Tibetan, notably Lama Tsongkhapa during the fourteenth century.

Understanding the structure and qualities of these stages is like having a road map for transforming life‚Äôs challenges and progressing step by step toward happiness, liberation, and enlightenment. In this module, we will study an overview of the path, including seminal texts, such as the Three Principal Aspects of the Path, and The Foundation of all Good Qualities.

This is the third in a series of 14 modules covering the complete Buddhist path to enlightenment. Students may join at any point in the cycle. Discovering Buddhism is designed for students who wish to deepen their understanding of fundamental Buddhist concepts. The program is designed to provide an experiential taste of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings and the skills we need to make our lives most meaningful. Each module includes teachings, meditations, readings, and assessment questions. A short retreat is offered at the end of the course.

*Nobody should be turned away from studying Dharma due to financial reasons. If the suggested course contribution feels too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students. Born in Venezuela of European parents, she was raised in Argentina and after completing a degree in Business Administration, she emigrated to New Zealand in 2004, where she first encountered Tibetan Buddhism. She took ordination in 2014 with the Great Master Lama Zopa Rinpoche. Since then she has engaged in formal Buddhist studies, including the completion of the Master Programme in Buddhist Philosophy. She has also spent months in solitary retreat including at Lawudo, a remote hermitage in the Himalayas, Nepal. She has served the FPMT for the past 20 years in various roles, and is currently the Resident Teacher at Yeshin Norbu Center in Stockholm. She has led various courses & retreats in NZ, Australia, Sweden, Colombia, India, Nepal and Germany. Her “international” background allows her to have an open, friendly and warm manner.

 

Course Preview

For more information about this module, watch this 26-minute video on Youtube:

Part of the internationally renowned Discovering Buddhism program, developed by the Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition (FPMT).

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we‚Äôll see how we can help.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Tuesdays 17, 24, 31 March, 14, 21, 28 April

About This Course

This spring, Venerable Khadro will¬† for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices, particularly one sadana adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche did on many occasions adviced his students to perform what he called “The Method to Transform a Suffering Life into Happiness” – a compilation of daily practices, including prayers, sadanas and meditations for both the beginning, middle and the end of the day.

Following Rinpoche’s advice Venerable Khadro will begin the year by introducing this essential daily practice. For more information about the practice, please read this short article, including a video about it.

The term is divided into three parts, each part run for about 7 weeks each, it is possible to register for the whole term or the various parts individually. Combined with these classes there will also be offered a number of related practice days and weekend retreats.

A prerequisite to participate in this course is that the student have undertaken the two year Discovering Buddhism course or equivalent.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. Rooted in the VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs rich lineage, this course explores the foundations of deity yoga, the stages of generation and completion, and the role of guru devotion, mantra, and visualization. We practice tantra not to escape the world, but to transmute it ‚Äî recognizing all appearances as expressions of enlightened mind. It is a path of fearless compassion, unshakable clarity, and skillful means. This course is intended for those who have studied the Lam Rim, are already grounded in the sutra path and ready to deepen their understanding of VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs profound methods.

In the event of any enquiries please reach out to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

 

Your Teacher

title: Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path
description:
Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path

Begin your journey into Buddhist philosophy and meditation with the third module of Discovering Buddhism. One does not need to be a Buddhist to join this course; it’s suitable for those students who are relatively new to buddhism and would like to gain a better understanding of the entire Buddhist path and also for more experienced students who wish to refresh their understanding of the stages of the path to enlightenment.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Thursdays 16, 23 April & Thursdays 7, 14, 21 May
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM CET
  • üè† Hybrid (in person at Yeshin Norbu/Stockholm and on zoom; recordings will be rent to participants)

About This Course

In this course you will gain a clear idea of the path to enlightenment, especially its three main components: renunciation, Bodhichitta, and the right view of emptiness. You will understand the progressive, step-like structure of the Buddhist path (Lam Rim), its origin in the teachings of Guru Shakyamuni Buddha, the three scopes, where you fit at your present stage of spiritual development, what you need to do next, and how you get from there to enlightenment.

The stages of the path to enlightenment (lamrim in Tibetan) are Shakyamuni Buddha‚Äôs original teachings presented as a logical and gradual system for learning to develop the mind. Arranged in Tibet by Lama Atisha in the eleventh century, the lamrim was subsequently elaborated by other great Tibetan, notably Lama Tsongkhapa during the fourteenth century.

Understanding the structure and qualities of these stages is like having a road map for transforming life‚Äôs challenges and progressing step by step toward happiness, liberation, and enlightenment. In this module, we will study an overview of the path, including seminal texts, such as the Three Principal Aspects of the Path, and The Foundation of all Good Qualities.

This is the third in a series of 14 modules covering the complete Buddhist path to enlightenment. Students may join at any point in the cycle. Discovering Buddhism is designed for students who wish to deepen their understanding of fundamental Buddhist concepts. The program is designed to provide an experiential taste of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings and the skills we need to make our lives most meaningful. Each module includes teachings, meditations, readings, and assessment questions. A short retreat is offered at the end of the course.

*Nobody should be turned away from studying Dharma due to financial reasons. If the suggested course contribution feels too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students. Born in Venezuela of European parents, she was raised in Argentina and after completing a degree in Business Administration, she emigrated to New Zealand in 2004, where she first encountered Tibetan Buddhism. She took ordination in 2014 with the Great Master Lama Zopa Rinpoche. Since then she has engaged in formal Buddhist studies, including the completion of the Master Programme in Buddhist Philosophy. She has also spent months in solitary retreat including at Lawudo, a remote hermitage in the Himalayas, Nepal. She has served the FPMT for the past 20 years in various roles, and is currently the Resident Teacher at Yeshin Norbu Center in Stockholm. She has led various courses & retreats in NZ, Australia, Sweden, Colombia, India, Nepal and Germany. Her “international” background allows her to have an open, friendly and warm manner.

 

Course Preview

For more information about this module, watch this 26-minute video on Youtube:

Part of the internationally renowned Discovering Buddhism program, developed by the Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition (FPMT).

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we‚Äôll see how we can help.

title: Green Tara Practice
description:
Green Tara Practice

Join us for Green Tara Puja together, a great way to promote inner strength and health for ourselves and others.

Event Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Friday April 24
  • üïï 6:00 – :7.30 PM including fika
  • üè† In Person

About This Event

We do Tara practice together. Group practices create a sense of belonging and add strength to our intentions. It is said that a solitary practice is like a spark, while a group practice is like a raging fire. When we practice together we get support from the group to make our practice more focused, intensive, and deep. The positive effects of our practice spread like ripples on water, so let‚Äôs contribute to peace in the world by practicing together!
In the end of the Green Tara Practice we dedicate the positive energy we have created by doing the practice to the well-being of all sentient beings. We pray and dedicate for individuals as well ‚Äì for sick, dying, dead, and for success in activities.
Feel free to send your dedications to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

Most Welcome!

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

title: Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path
description:
Discovering Buddhism: Presenting the Path

Begin your journey into Buddhist philosophy and meditation with the third module of Discovering Buddhism. One does not need to be a Buddhist to join this course; it’s suitable for those students who are relatively new to buddhism and would like to gain a better understanding of the entire Buddhist path and also for more experienced students who wish to refresh their understanding of the stages of the path to enlightenment.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Thursdays 16, 23 April & Thursdays 7, 14, 21 May
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM CET
  • üè† Hybrid (in person at Yeshin Norbu/Stockholm and on zoom; recordings will be rent to participants)

About This Course

In this course you will gain a clear idea of the path to enlightenment, especially its three main components: renunciation, Bodhichitta, and the right view of emptiness. You will understand the progressive, step-like structure of the Buddhist path (Lam Rim), its origin in the teachings of Guru Shakyamuni Buddha, the three scopes, where you fit at your present stage of spiritual development, what you need to do next, and how you get from there to enlightenment.

The stages of the path to enlightenment (lamrim in Tibetan) are Shakyamuni Buddha‚Äôs original teachings presented as a logical and gradual system for learning to develop the mind. Arranged in Tibet by Lama Atisha in the eleventh century, the lamrim was subsequently elaborated by other great Tibetan, notably Lama Tsongkhapa during the fourteenth century.

Understanding the structure and qualities of these stages is like having a road map for transforming life‚Äôs challenges and progressing step by step toward happiness, liberation, and enlightenment. In this module, we will study an overview of the path, including seminal texts, such as the Three Principal Aspects of the Path, and The Foundation of all Good Qualities.

This is the third in a series of 14 modules covering the complete Buddhist path to enlightenment. Students may join at any point in the cycle. Discovering Buddhism is designed for students who wish to deepen their understanding of fundamental Buddhist concepts. The program is designed to provide an experiential taste of the Buddha‚Äôs teachings and the skills we need to make our lives most meaningful. Each module includes teachings, meditations, readings, and assessment questions. A short retreat is offered at the end of the course.

*Nobody should be turned away from studying Dharma due to financial reasons. If the suggested course contribution feels too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students. Born in Venezuela of European parents, she was raised in Argentina and after completing a degree in Business Administration, she emigrated to New Zealand in 2004, where she first encountered Tibetan Buddhism. She took ordination in 2014 with the Great Master Lama Zopa Rinpoche. Since then she has engaged in formal Buddhist studies, including the completion of the Master Programme in Buddhist Philosophy. She has also spent months in solitary retreat including at Lawudo, a remote hermitage in the Himalayas, Nepal. She has served the FPMT for the past 20 years in various roles, and is currently the Resident Teacher at Yeshin Norbu Center in Stockholm. She has led various courses & retreats in NZ, Australia, Sweden, Colombia, India, Nepal and Germany. Her “international” background allows her to have an open, friendly and warm manner.

 

Course Preview

For more information about this module, watch this 26-minute video on Youtube:

Part of the internationally renowned Discovering Buddhism program, developed by the Foundation for the Preservation of the Mahayana Tradition (FPMT).

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we‚Äôll see how we can help.

title: Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro¬†– For more experienced students – Part 3
description:
Lojong, Daily Practice and Nongdro – For more experienced students

This spring, Venerable Khadro will for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Course Details

üó£Ô∏è With Venerable Khadro

  • üìÖ Tuesdays 5, 12, 19, 26 May, 2, 9 June
  • üïï 6:00 – 8:00 PM including Fika
  • üè† Hybrid

About This Course

This spring, Venerable Khadro will¬† for more experienced students introduce how to implement a daily practice in the everyday, including how to set up a home altar, how to perform water bowl offerings, how to do preliminary practices such as making tsatsas and mandala offerings as well as explain various Tibetan Buddhist rituals and practices, particularly one sadana adviced and compiled by Lama Zopa Rinpoche called the ‘Method practice’.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche did on many occasions adviced his students to perform what he called “The Method to Transform a Suffering Life into Happiness” – a compilation of daily practices, including prayers, sadanas and meditations for both the beginning, middle and the end of the day.

Following Rinpoche’s advice Venerable Khadro will begin the year by introducing this essential daily practice. For more information about the practice, please read this short article, including a video about it.

The term is divided into three parts, each part run for about 7 weeks each, it is possible to register for the whole term or the various parts individually. Combined with these classes there will also be offered a number of related practice days and weekend retreats.

A prerequisite to participate in this course is that the student have undertaken the two year Discovering Buddhism course or equivalent.

For qualified practitioners, tantra offers the means to achieve Buddhahood swiftly by directly accessing the subtlest levels of mind. Rooted in the VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs rich lineage, this course explores the foundations of deity yoga, the stages of generation and completion, and the role of guru devotion, mantra, and visualization. We practice tantra not to escape the world, but to transmute it ‚Äî recognizing all appearances as expressions of enlightened mind. It is a path of fearless compassion, unshakable clarity, and skillful means. This course is intended for those who have studied the Lam Rim, are already grounded in the sutra path and ready to deepen their understanding of VajrayƒÅna‚Äôs profound methods.

In the event of any enquiries please reach out to spc@yeshinnorbu.se.

 

Your Teacher

Venerable Khadro brings years of experience teaching Buddhist philosophy and meditation in the tradition of His Holiness the Dalai Lama. Her clear and practical approach makes profound Buddhist concepts accessible to modern students.

Our policy in regards to tickets is that no-one should be turned away from Dharma classes due to financial reasons. If the suggested course donation seems too much for you, please let us know (spc@yeshinnorbu.se) and we’ll see how we can help.

title: Animal Liberation Day
description:
Welcome to this kids and pets friendly whole day event!

Last year we did the practice of¬†animal¬†liberation¬†with Venerable Michael and a few members of Yeshin Norbu sangha at the¬†stupa in Fellingsbro. This Buddhist stupa that was built in the 80s and was consecrated by His Holiness the Dalai Lama during one of His Holiness’ visits.

What is¬†animal¬†liberation¬†practice?¬†

Animal¬†liberation¬†is one of the heart practices of Lama Zopa Rinpoche. Whenever possible, Rinpoche rescues¬†animals¬†like goats which are on the way to the slaughter house. Such¬†animals¬†are sent to the¬†animal¬†sanctuary afterwards.¬†Rinpoche liberates even small insects.

Lama Zopa Rinpoche recommends¬†animal¬†liberation¬†as a specific practice done for¬†animals¬†who would otherwise be killed, such as¬†livestock, bait worms, and live feeder insects. The practice involves taking the endangered¬†animals¬†around holy objects, reciting mantras for them, blessing water to sprinkle onto their bodies, and then releasing them. Rinpoche teaches that the practice benefits¬†animal¬†spiritually and is an incredible practice for anyone who is ill or experiencing life obstacles.¬†Animal¬†blessings, on the other hand, involve blessing¬†animals¬†with¬†mantras or holy objects, even if they are not in danger.

Also, practices of¬†animal¬†liberation¬†are done for the long lives of our teachers.

You can read more here:

When one does¬†animal¬†liberation, one circumambulates holy objects and recites mantras for the rescued beings.¬†Animal¬†liberation¬†is not only about saving¬†animals¬†from the immediate threat, but also giving them Dharma. In that way one practices love – freeing from fear and generosity of Dharma.

Last year we¬†liberated¬†a few hundreds worms which were supposed to be used as fish bait. We will do the same this year.

If you wish to donate for purchasing worms to be saved, you can make a donation below.¬†

You can take your pets with you to circumambulate the stupa.¬†In that way you can help them purify their negative karma by going around the stupa.

On Saturday May 18th¬†we will go to Fellingsbro, 2-2,5 hours drive from Stockholm. We will do the practice and then have a potluck picnic there. Please bring vegan dishes. If you plan to go from Stockholm and have a car, please let us know by email to hello@yeshinnorbu by May 16th, and we can help organize a car-pooling.

Please also email us your dedications if you cannot go, we will read the names in the end of the practice and dedicate for them. It is a whole day event.
